STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 17, 2023
Jennifer Keller
Wolverine Human Services Aftercare
20300 Superior Rd, Ste 140
Taylor, MI, 48180-6302
RE: License#: CB820201514
Dear Ms. Keller:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820201514
Licensee Group Organization: Wolverine Human Services
Licensee Designee: Judith Wollack
Chief Administrator: Jennifer Keller
Name of Agency: Wolverine Human Services Aftercare
Agency Address: 20300 Superior Rd
Ste 140
Taylor, MI 48180-6302
Agency Telephone #: 3132956264
Original Issuance Date: 07/01/1992
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 9/20/2023-9/26/2023
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed
Current licensed foster homes 60 7
Homes pending licensure 14 3
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 25 4
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 3 3
Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 6 5
Incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect
in foster care since last inspection 1 1
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 1 1
Children receiving direct foster care case management (placement in foster homes,
relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 134 8
Children discharged from care during this period 63 8
Youth in independent living placement 4 3
Youth discharged from an independent living placement
since the last inspection 7 3
Applicants approved for adoption since the last inspection 39 6
Applicants denied for adoption since the last inspection 7 3
Closed child adoption cases since the last inspection 37 6
Open child adoption cases 48 6
Current employees who have worked at the facility for:
More than a year 29 8
Less than a year 7 7
Persons Interviewed:
Licensing Staff 1
Foster Care Staff 2
Adoption Staff 1
Supervisory Staff 2
Administrative Staff 3

B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
Licensed foster homes 50 3
Unlicensed relative homes 50 3
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 3
Foster Children 8
Relatives 3
Others (identify person interviewed by role) N/A
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on
central registry.
(2) A staff member must be of responsible character
and suitable and able to met the needs od children and
families served by the agency.
To aid in ensuring ongoing compliance of this rule, the agency mandates
completion of annual ICHAT and central registry clearances for its employees.
Of 15 employee records reviewed, three, where the employee was employed
over a year, did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of a 2022 ICHAT clearance due
by 12/6/2022. The ICHAT clearance was completed on 1/9/2023.
• A second record showed the ICHAT clearance was due by 3/7/2023 and
completed late on 3/20/2023. This employee’s annual central registry
clearance was due by 3/18/2023 and completed late on 3/28/2023.
• A third record showed the ICHAT clearance was due by 12/6/2022 and
completed late on 1/9/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3)The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s
performance within a probationay period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or

her current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation,
a written evaluation must be conducted every 12
months.
One of 15 employee records reviewed did not show documentation of an annual
written evaluation for the employee, which was due by 7/1/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation,
an agency shall complete a written report that includes
all of the following information:
(c) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children
are interviewed, their last names may not be included
in the report.
One of five special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation of all dates
of contacts for all persons interviewed or place of contact for each person
interviewed.
Repeat Violation Renewal 2021, cited under prior rule (5)(d).
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violatons are cited and there is a signed
corrective action plan, all social service workers who
have children placed in the home must be notified there
is a corrective action plan and what is required of the
foster parent in that plan.
One of five special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation of
notification to all workers as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both of the following must
be documented before a change in placement.
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up
to the time of the change in placement and the needs
that remain to be met.
One of eight closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
(a) as required by the rule.

Repeat Violation- Renewal 2021.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both of the following must
be documented before a change in placement.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of eight closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
(b) a required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2021.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of 29 updated service plans reviewed, one was three days late.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2021.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plan.
(1)The initial service plan, as required in
R400.12418(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R400.12404(4).
One of two initial service plans reviewed did not show documentation of (c) as
required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plan.
(1)An updated service plan, as required in
R400.12418(2)(b), must include all the following
information:
(g) A child behavior support plan that includes any
changes made since the previous plan and is to be
used by the foster parents.

Of 29 updated service plan reviewed, where 18 related to foster children, two
service plans( related to two of eight foster child records reviewed) did not show
documentation of a specific behavior support plan to be used by the foster parent.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022, Renewal 2021.
FOM 722 6B Family Team Meeting
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents,
caretakers, foster parents, children, youth, and may
also include extended family, friends, neighbors,
community-based service providers,
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate
forms must be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of a
FTM for the respective child’s 2/16/2023- 5/15/2023 and 7/9/2022-10/6/2022
updated service plan.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022, Renewal 2021.
FOM 722-D Treatment Plan.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
Five of 31 service plans reviewed (related to three of eight foster child records
reviewed) did not show compliance:
• One child’s 10/7/2022-1/3/2023 and 1/4/2023-4/2/2023 updated service
plans were not dated by the caregiver. It could not be discerned if the
respective plan was signed timely, per the standard.

• A second child’s 12/11/2022-3/9/2023 and 3/10/2023-6/6/2023 updated
service plan’s were not dated by the caregiver. It could not be discerned if
the respective plan was signed timely, per the standard.
• A third child’s 5/8/2023-6/6/2023 initial service plan was not dated by the
caregiver. It could not be discerned if the caregiver signed the plan timely,
per the standard.
Repeat Violation Interim 2022; Renewal 2021 cited under 722-8C
FOM 801-C Medical Passport.
Initial medical passport:
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child's placement date to the following.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect
the child's current and complete health information.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• Two records did not show documentation that the caregiver was provided
a copy ot the child’s medical passport within two weeks of the placement.
• A third record did not show documentation of a March or June 2023
medical passport.
Repeat Violation Interim 2022; Renewal 2021 cited under MISEP 6.49
MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of
conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
department, bureau of fire services, or local
authorities; records; report; forms; confidentiality;
disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be
provided to department; failure of licensee to
cooperate with investigation, inspection, or
examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care
and shall report to the department, when requested,
the facts the department requires with reference to the
children upon forms furnished by the department.
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection and
subsection (4), records regarding children and facts
compiled about children and their parents and relatives
are confidential and disclosure of this information shall

be properly safeguarded by the child care organization,
the department, and any other entity in possession of
the information. Records that are confidential under this
section are available to both of the following:
One of five special evaluations reviewed indicated CPS(child proctective
services) and MIC(Maltreatment in care) language and showed CPS’s
involvement in the investigation.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12607(4) Agency recommendations.
• The agency is apprised it shall be timelier with providing the family a copy of
the adoptive family assessment.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Nothing this inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
It encompassed three complaints for one foster home.
The incident related to a foster home complaint the agency received in late
November 2022. The complaint alleged the foster mother and her spouse who had
moved into the home used spanking to discipline the five-year-old foster child.
During the course of the investigation the evidence showed the foster mother’s
spouse and the spouse’s children had moved into the home with the foster parent
without the family composition change being reported to the agency. The foster
child, as well as other children in the home reported that the foster child and the
adopted child in the home had been physically disciplined. Discipline took the form
of spanking with a belt or paddle. During the initial phase of the investigation the
agency developed a safety plan with the foster parent; and upon the interviews
showing evidence of physical discipline the foster child was replaced from the home
and the investigation continued. After a lengthy investigation, the foster home was
found in violation of the behavior management rule, in addition to the reporting of
foster home changes rule, foster home applicant/licensee qualification rule, record
check rule, foster home evaluation rule related to truthfulness; and the foster parent
duties rule related to maintaining a copy of agency policies. Revocation of the
foster home’s license was recommended.
This foster home received two subsequent complaints against it, one in April 2023
and another in July 2023. The allegations connected to or were a form of repeated

allegations related to the investigation the agency was conducting. The foster home
refused to interact further with the agency on these complaints; and the agency
sought the guidance of the Division of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) on what to
do/how to precede related to these special evaluations. The agency affirmed its
recommendation related to these complaints.
The agency adhered to departmental rules related to the incidents and appeared to
have acted appropriately.
There were one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
This incident related to a foster home complaint alleging that the foster father hit the
child in the stomach and dragged the child on the carpet. During the investigation
the foster parents denied the allegations; but admitted that the foster father tapped
the child on the child’s bottom, while the child was clothed. The foster father
reported this was the only thing that stopped the child from attacking the child’s
foster sister. The agency found the foster home in violation of the behavior
management policy. A corrective action plan was developed with the foster parents
that included training related to, Rearing Resilience: Strategies for Parenting
Children with Attachment Trauma; and Parenting the Positive Discipline Way.
The agency adhered to all departmental standards related to this incident, except
R400.12327(7); and 722.120(3) for which the agency received a violation, as
indicated earlier in this report.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period. The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2022
Interim inspection were it received the following rule violations:
• R400.12413(1) (c)(ii) Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12418(2)(a) Development of service plans
• R400.12419(1)(c) Initial service plans.
• R400.12510(2) Independent living contract.
• R400.12607(4) Agency recommendation.
• FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
• FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans-Overview, Types, And Time frames.
Supervisor Approval.
• FOM 722-8D Treatment plan. Agreement and signature.
• FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
• FOM 722-15 Discharge documents.
• FOM 801-3 Medical passport.
• FOM 802 Mental Health and Behavioral and Developmental Needs o
children under Supervision of MDHHS.
Despite the repeat violations as indicated in this report, the agency made
significant progress with this corrective action plan. The agency provided proof of
training it indicated would occur. Showed samples of supervisor/worker biweekly
supervision showing continued discussions and focus with workers on adoption
family assessment submissions to adoptive families, quarterly adoption progress
reports, child adoption assessments and effort to move a child’s adoption plan
forward. They also provided information showing reminders were given to staff on
required foster care tasks and the case record reviews demonstrated the agency’s
efforts towards correcting the violations.
The agency’s second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation
2023C042000050. The complaint allegations were received on 2/24/2023. The
complaint alleged that the agency was provided a safety alert in September 2022
and not all of the issues were resolved. That the agency moved a youth based on
some unresolved issues, and additional issues, leaving five children in an unsafe
home. The special investigation found the agency in violation of R400.12404(4)(b)
related to the physical, emotional, and educational needs of the child; that the
children were left in a placement that was unsafe for several months.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in April 2023, that
indicated a safety protocol on R 400.12404 would be completed, along with a
training for foster care department staff on placements, on all types of safety
concerns, and agency procedures. The agency completed this corrective action
plan, proof of such was verified 8/18/2023.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency provided a chief administrator's report dated 9/5/2023. The report was
completed per rule standards.

Financial Overview
The agency provided a projected budget, and 9/30/2022 annual financial audit.
The financial information is as documented; no specific issues were noted.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to my engagement with the agency's chief administrator and five
administrative staff, I interviewed two foster care specialists, one licensing
specialist, one adoption specialist and two adoptive parents. The interviewees all
reported positive remarks about the agency and services the agency provides and
promotes.
Other than an adoptive parent expressing concern about the amount of paperwork
involved in the adoption process; a worker indicating a need for the agency to
continue respecting the employees’ home life with respective to long work hours
and trying to strike a balance; and another worker expressing a desire for the
agency to provide finance support to employees around the wear and tear on
workers' vehicles, no other limitations or concerns were indicated.
Three youth interviews were attempted; one was completed. The youth reported
praise for her individual worker; and that she would recommend the agency’s
independent living program. She recommended that the agency work on being
able to provide funds for more emergency type expenses that may surface for
youths.
Description of Agency Walk Through
I conducted a tour of the agency's building, and no concerns or safety issues were
observed.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings, the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
_____________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date October 12, 2023
Licensing Consultant

Approved By:
10/17/2023
_____________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Pifer Date
Area Manager
